Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Solid-State Sensors and Actuators Workshop (Hilton Head 2012). To be held June 3-7, 2012 in Hilton Head, NC.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Solid-State Sensors and Actuators Workshop (Hilton Head 2012)
Intellectual Merit:
The workshop will disseminate MEMS research and technology breakthroughs. The workshop consists
of 26 contributed oral papers, and 89 contributed posters. There will also be an open poster
session where recent work (and educational programs) can be discussed.
Broader Impact:
The workshop will have broad impact for the entire MEMS community. The knowledge gained and
experiences shared from the workshop will be captured electronically and broadly disseminated
via a website. By receiving travel support, students will get the opportunity to present their
newest research results among their peers. The discussions which result from such presentations
are invaluable as an educational aid. Benefiting from the recommendations and improved teaching
and training, students will be better prepared for both MEMS research and MEMS-focused careers

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to increase US graduate and undergraduate student participation in the 2012 Solid-State Sensors and Actuators Workshop (Hilton Head 2012).  The workshop is the main event in America to share and disseminate most recent research results on MEMS practices.  The workshop agenda includes plenary speakers from academia and industry to discuss state-of-the-art in research areas of solid-state sensors and actuators in micro/nanosystems. The four plenary talks include: "IT MAKES SENSE: HOW EXTREME ANALOG AND SENSING WILL CHANGE THE WORLD" by Benedetto Vigna from STMicroelectronics, "WIRELESS IMPLANTABLE MICROSYSTEMS: CREATING A REVOLUTION IN HEALTH CARE" by Kensall Wise from University of Michigan, "HOW WIRELESS HEALTH WILL CHANGE HEALTH CARE DELIVERY," by Mark Zdeblick from Proteus Biomedical, Inc., and "SIMPLE BIOANALYSIS" by George Whitesides from Harvard University.  There were 26 oral presentations, and 89 posters.  With travel support from NSF, we were able to partially support 14 student presenters to attend the meeting.

The workshop has broad impact for the entire MEMS community. The knowledge gained and experiences shared from the workshop were captured electronically and broadly disseminated via a website. By receiving travel support, students got the opportunity to present their newest research results among their peers. The discussions which result from such presentations
are invaluable as an educational aid. Benefiting from the recommendations and improved teaching and training, students will be better prepared for both MEMS research and MEMS-focused careers.
